reviewText: The metro, which is mostly underground in the center, is only part of the city rail passenger transport system. It consists of two lines with a length of 43 kilometers with 35 stations. The first one is blue, opened in 2004. The second Purple Line opened on August 6, 2016, and on August 11, 2017, the two lines were connected via an interchange station. The city's plans include a very serious increase in the number of stations, the length of lines and the addition of at least one more branch. The metro is very clean. The depth of the stations is small. Spacious. Clear ticket sales system. So far I see one serious drawback - trains rarely run! reviewTitle: Easy to use.  Cheap, cheerful and efficient!
reviewText: I used this a few times only. I mainly used the BTS. The MRT services more local areas and some tourist attractions.Â  Appears to be busier than the BTS as more locals use it! Air conditioning is not as cold!Â  Cheap to use and interchange should you also need to use the BTS.Â  Staff are helpful and the self - service ticket machines are easy to use.Â  Stations are clean and big.Â  Follow the signs as there are many entrances / exits.Â  The ticket mainly appears to be a token the size of a coin which is easy to loose so be careful!Â  I just got single journey tickets.Â  Not sure if you can get daily or multiple.Â  You cannot purchase a combination ticket MRT / BTS.Â  Totally separate.Â  Average single journey is around THB 30.00.Â  Download an application from google play which will help you plan your journey and manage timings.Â  Safe to use.Â  You cannot eat or drink in stations or on trains.Â  At the time of C-19, masks must be worn.Â  Taxis in Bangkok are awful.Â  Expensive and drivers don't know the roads well.Â  This is a cheap and cheerful way to commute around.Â  Efficient and timely.Â

reviewTitle: The best place for clean air in Bangkok
reviewText:
Most users are glad we now have a reasonable subway running in Bangkok.
I agree with other comments that a common ticket with BTS would be helpful.

I disagree with the problems with tokens - which is correct if just jusing it rarely.
But everyone can buy a value-store card - including rebates - with ease (and ID).
Yet, thousands of Thais prefer to cue every day, instead of putting 100 Baht into a card (which is about 3 UDS).

The good news: considering the horrible pollution in BBK's air, we measured the particles, namely the 2.5 ppm at the big exchange station Asok/Sukhumvit. To our surprise, at MRT level the air was 5-10 times CLEANER than at ground level. So, the air filtering and climatization there is excellent.

A pity there are nearly no seats or benches to sit down and breathe clean air for longer.

P.S. The optional questions about this "attraction" make nt alot of sense, since we talk about a public transport system. And asking about "Veterans" and discounts is rather an American gimmick - insulting for other countries even, who have their own thinking about US Veterans.
I strongly recommend asking for "Senior Citizen" discounts instead!
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Blue Line extension is a godsend
reviewText:
That the Bangkok Metro is continually being extended is testimony to its ready acceptance by locals and tourists alike.

Its 2019 Blue Line extension past Hua Lamphong means Chinatown and the Chao Praya River boats are more accessible than ever.

Trains are frequent, clean, reliable, fast between stations and safe. Escalators and lifts make access easy. Station staff at fare gates are helpful.

There is an easy connection at Phetchaburi to the Airport rail line.

The newest stations are beautifully designed, such as Sanam Choi.

Fares are cheap: THB42 from HL to Silom single.

Why add to traffic congestion by using a taxi, GRAB or auto rickshaw when the MRT is such a winner?

reviewTitle: Not a place, but a service.
reviewText:
This review is a little out of the ordinary in that I usually review a hotel or restaurant. This concerns a service.

reviewTitle: Great way to get about Bangkok
reviewText:
The Bangkok metro is wonderful: efficient, comfortable with clean and easily negotiated stations and also. Very cheap.

At present there are two lines with the Blue Line being the most useful for visitors. It connects with the Airport BTS at Petchaburi and the BTS at Sukhumvit as well as Hua Lamphong train station. Also use for Lumpini Park and the eastern end of Silom Road.

Fares are cheaper than the BTS: on the Metro you are issued with tokens rather than cards but travel follows the same principles as on the BTS. Staff at ticket offices all seem to have a good command of English and English signage is available throughout.

The line has been recently extended to the west beyond Hua Lamphong across the river, and this is very useful to visitors. The stop at Sanam Chai is really, really convenient to Wat Pho, Museum Siam, the river and everything in the Grand palace/Rattonisokin area.

Also, if you are over 60, ask for senior tickets: half price on an already cheap ticket.

reviewTitle: GOOD IN THIS BIG CITY - BUT ACCEPTS PRIMARILY CASH(NO CARDS)
reviewText:
Like any big city this is a valuable way to get around but overwhelming with large number of stations with challengingly similiar names..

I was surprized to find that most ticket/token machines DO NOT TAKE CREDIT CARDS. So try to arrive with BAHT small bills(100 or smaller) or coinage otherwise you will have to wait in lines just to get change.

Another observation was that once you select a fare option and pay you will get your change PLUS A BLACK PLASTIC TOKEN. Whereas in most other cities you would get a paper ticket.

At the ENTRY turnstile take the BLACK PLASTIC TOKEN and hold it over the display screen on the turnstile.

At the EXIT turnstile deposit the token into the slot to exit.

So again, be sure to grab your change AND black plastic token.

ONE IMPORTANT SIDE NOTE: En route to a site I found that there are pockets/areas of the city that are not close/convient to stations. So i reccomend you plan ahead as it may be prudent to go to a station and grab a cab to your destination otherwise it may involve some considerable walking.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText: I used to use BTS every day. I lived in Bangkok for the better part of eight years. BTS was the quickest and cheapest way to get around town and avoid rush hour traffic. Getting a seat can sometimes be a problem, but you have to persevere and keep your eyes open and you will get a place at least for part of your trip. As an older man, however, I found young people most often unwilling to give their seats to an elderly passenger, especially if they are Caucasian.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText: The MRT is essentially a mainly underground rail network throughout Bangkok and Metro Bangkok, in contrast to the Sky Train or BTS, which is essentially above ground. The MRT network is being extended considerably, to bring in more outlying areas, which at present are plagued with traffic jams getting into work from 5 am onwards!  That in turn will help to raise the value of properties in those areas!

reviewText:
The Bangkok MRT, along with the BTS Skytrain and Airport Rail Link, make up Bangkok's attempt to alleviate its horrendous traffic problems. So far its extent is limited. The trains are quick and smooth but crowded. Lots of standing room at the expense of seating.
But these are three separate systems. Ticketing is incompatible. To get from Hua Lumpong to Ratchaprarop I had to use all three systems. This involved standing in line for three different tickets. Maybe a stored value card would avoid this? Even the interchange stations have a different name on each line. How could they make such a dog's breakfast of a system? Why didn't the government knock some heads together and squash these ego problems?

reviewTitle: The Bangkok "underground" is about to blossom
reviewText:
The Bangkok underground, the MRT is about to blossom with lines being finished, new stations springing up and new rolling stock in the near future.
The existing trans provide the most rapid transport around the areas served already, a
very civilised way to travel, the trains and the stations are kept spotless and some of the stations are huge having been built to accommodate the future travellers in comfort.It takes about 2 years to build a train set and while some overcrowding is now being experienced the MRT commuter can soon expect some relief.
One of the quirky things about the MRT is that passengers of any nationality aged over 60 years can travel at half price, all that is required is to show you passport when buying a stored value ticket.
Through 2019/20 a total of 4 lines will be completed making commuting easier.
Step on board and experience Bangkok's hidden gem
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText:
In conjunction with the BTS (skytrain), the MRT is a great way to get around Bangkok without getting caught in the often standstill congestion. The trains comes often, so even if you encounter one that's too crowded during rush hour, you'll only have to wait a few minutes for the next one. Buying a ticket is easy too.

There are multiple MRT expansions and new lines being built, so this system will only get more useful.

reviewTitle: know your route! great alternative to BTS
reviewText: the mrt in bangkok is excellent if you know your route...in the sukhumvit area, which i will address as this is where most people are oriented, runs in a general direction of the bts but offers stops that may be closer to an attraction of area that you wish to visit...also, the mrt may be the faster, less crowded choice to to areas such as SIAM.....check your map...if you see that the MRT is close to the area that you wish to visit, you may want to choose the MRT.....also,...if you are in bangkok for a few days...get the MRT card...dont que up with the locals who tend to buy point to point tickets....those lines are LONG...spend a few baht, get the card, top it off....much easier and faster and a great keepsake....same with the BTS..get the RABBIT card, top it off and go to the automated gates....

reviewText:
MRT/ Bangkok Airport Rail Link:

I started my first day of adventure in finding out how to reach Bangkok MRT by checking where the bus station is. In short I got Bus #35 straight to Hua Lamphong and noticed it passes by the Chinatown.

Upon reaching Hua Lamphong station my curiosity directed me to go to the last of the MRT station to complete its running details.

In coming back I got off at Phetchaburi station where Bangkok Airport Rail Link, a commuter rail line connecting Suvarnabhumi Airport to Phaya Thai (BTS) station via Makkasan Station.

If only earlier I had the idea how to find this Bangkok Airport Rail Link I should have not spent that much and being scammed by the driver of the taxi from the airport. If anyone asks me how to use the MRT and the Airport Rail Link I could save them lots of travel budget and time.

reviewTitle: This is what public transit should be in every city
reviewText: For a city of 8 million people, the MRT and Sky Train systems are what every city should have, and are really the only effective way to move about the city without being impacted by traffic congestion.  The trains are quiet, spacious (even at rush hours), public address and signage systems are excellent, climate control is superb, and everything works extraordinarily well.  We saw no signs of pan handling, crime, hustling, fare evasion or the filth that we encounter daily where we live. We live in the San Francisco Bay Area, where no public transit system comes anywhere close to the quality of Bangkok's two rail systems.  The contrast is striking.

reviewText: Most tourists travelling to Bangkok have heard of, or are familiar with Bangkok's Skytrain - The BTS. But if you are not quite so familiar with the MRT - it is definitely worth checking up on. Check the route and the stations. It can save a lot of time between certain stations. ASOK to SILOM for example. So, fast and not as full as the BTS - outside of rush hour. The disadvantages? It's a seperate system to the other rail services - the ARL & BTS. You need another stored value ticket. The stations don't have a direct link or bridge to the shopping malls - unlike the BTS. The link between the BTS and the MRT can be a bit awkward. I use Phetchaburi Station most of all. It links via a walkway to the ARL Station - Makkasan. And even with luggage is not too bad (I'm 63) BUT there is a luggage security check at the station entrance. Not usually, but once in a while I have to open one bag at least. So, if you plan on being in BKK for a few days, it is worth buying a MRT stored value ticket, along with your RABBIT card and try the MRT. When you return to your home country, you can always pas on the MRT ticket to a friend to use, if you not planning on a return visit to BKK soon.

reviewTitle: More convenient travel option for the elderly than Sky train
reviewText: The MRT is newer than the overhead sky train and benefits form air conditioning on the platforms, wider stations and convenience of access with escalators on almost all entry points.   I travelled with my parents in their 70s, and they found this aspect much better than climbing stairs into the sky train system, though of course the MRT has a smaller service offering it does take you directly to the Chatuchak weekend market and other attractions such as the train night market at the Thailand Cultural Center.  There are plenty of ticket machines but the touch screens are not always working efficiently and itâ€™s easier to simply queue for the counter assistants to buy a ticket, they understand and speak English well. If youâ€™re over 60 itâ€™s worth asking for a seniorâ€™s ticket though often the staff donâ€™t believe you look your age, which is flattering at least! The only downsides to the MRT are that no toilets are provided as also is the case with the sky train  and services arenâ€™t as frequent as say in other major metropolitan areas overseas. If you want to avoid the heat and enjoy usually less cramped carriages than the sky train then this is a great option. Very reasonably priced.

reviewText:
If ever wanting to get to some locations in Bangkok in a hurry, take the MRT underground train.

The train system hits many city locations and for a fraction of the price it would cost for say a taxicab.

However, as one might imagine, if utilized during the rush hour periods, it WILL be very crowded.
That being said, it's very rapid in getting from place to place, and has nice cool air conditioning.

Finally, if you're a "frequent flyer" (user) of this train system (haha), you can obtain a special 'M' card at the ticket booths where you'll pay a small deposit, and can then top up for as much as you want, whenever you want, and then won't have to fiddle around with waiting in line to pay in cash or coins at the machines or maned booths and only getting a one time card for that trip.
That way, with the special 'M' card you can hit multiple stations just by scanning the card any time without having to pay for each trip with money.
AND...as an additional feature, (and at any time), you can turn the card in to the ticket booths to get a refund if you do not wish to use it any longer.
They have a small menu at the ticket booths showing the different M cards available and prices and are very inexpensive so check them out if you think you may be using MRT multiple times.

reviewTitle: Not as convenient as the BTS
reviewText: Long cavernous empty walks to get to the stations. Buying tickets for the underground MRT always seems inconvenient -- long queues for the machines, and coins required to buy the ticket -- so often two lines are in order, one to exchange notes, the other to actually buy the ticket.  Candidly, I prefer the above ground BTS as there are views, instead of feeling slightly claustrophobic.  In all, however, this is a thoroughly modern, extremely clean travel experience for a subway, especially when compared to cities like Sydney and New York.  And usually quicker, but not always cheaper (especially when travelling with friends) than a private taxi.

reviewText: Access to Hua Lampong Train Station metro line comes off the Bang Wa BTS line.  You have to make your way to BTS Sala Daeng and exit the BTS system.  The walk is about 10 mins and signage is not obvious to the MRT.  Just ask but don't let anyone ask you if they can help, they will try and get you you to go somewhere else.  Simply say NYET.  Then they know you don't speak english and will leave you alone.  When in the MRT system, you have to buy another pass (this time a black coin that is used the same way as the BTS system.  Don't lose the coin, as you need it for exit.  The system was quite quiet both days we used it to get to and from Hua Lampong.  After getting off, it is a fair underground walk.  You arrive at a 19th century train station that still has the commodities of 20th century.

reviewText:
I always take the MRT or bangkok metro to Chinatown (Hua Lamphong station), Terminal 21 (Sukhumvit station), Chatuchak or JJ market (Kampheng Phet station) whenever I visit Bangkok as it is fast, reliable and convenient. No more tuk tuk or metered-taxi bringing you to Diamond Factory before reaching your destination or overcharging you when the shopping mall is near closing time.

However, during my visit last week, I was disappointed with MRT unlike BTS as it is no longer pro-tourism by stopping to sell the day pass. So be prepared to buy the top up MRT card for THB180.00 with THB100.00 value, THB50.00 refundable deposit and THB30.00 non-refundable card fee. The validity of the card is two years. No rebate or discount for using the card at all if you are an adult. For school children, also same price but enjoy a 10% discount on the fare.

reviewTitle: State of the art subway system
reviewText: Clean, efficient, user friendly and fast. The MRT, along with Skytrain, has revolutionized travel in Bangkok and provided a standard other traffic clogged cities should emulate. However, here's the problem: They didn't integrate the MRT with Skytrain. So, two totally independent mass transit systems in the same dense city using two different ticketing systems. Plus, if you want to head into the emerging delights of Chinatown or the vast territiories surrounding the Grand Palace, you're still on your feet or have to persuade reluctant taxi drivers to brave the traffic over there.

Quick and easy way to get around. Not to mention escape from the heat and humidity. Like all transport systems world wide it gets pretty crowded during peak times.

reviewText: The MRT is the subway system in Bangkok, and is primarily used by the locals.  As a subway, it doesn't offer pretty views like the BTS Skytrain, but it is slightly less expensive and will take you to areas not served by the BTS.  Your "ticket" is a little plastic coin - hang onto it, as you'll need it to get off at your destination.  The stations seem to be unnecessarily large and occasionally difficult to navigate, but most signage is in thai and English.  Not quite as clean as the BTS, but a fast, easy way to get from place to place in Bangkok without having to hire a taxi.  There are a couple of stations along the routes that allow easy transfer between the MRT and the BTS - the combination of the two, particularly in conjunction with the river taxis, allows you to get just about anywhere you'd need to go

reviewTitle: Bangkok Subway - Air Conditioned, Inexpensive and Fast Way to Get Around the City
reviewText:
MRT is Bangkokâ€™s subway system and is an air conditioned, fast, safe, clean and inexpensive way to get around the city; it has two lines to cover different ends of Bangkok: blue line and purple line. Bangkok also has a skytrain system called the BTS (made up of two lines also, the Sukhumvit and Silom lines), also air conditioned, fast, clean, safe and inexpensive way to get around the city. Both systems have maps at the stations, good signage (including English) and well marked stops. There are a couple of interchange stations (Silom and Sukhumvit MRT stations) where you can transfer from the MRT to the BTS (and vice versa) to fast track you to your destination.

Bangkok is such a heavily traffic congested city so the MRT and BTS are excellent transportation alternatives to quickly get around the city and avoid sitting in traffic jams.

Donâ€™t shy away from using the MRT and the BTS to get around Bangkok just because youâ€™re a visitor. Comparable to the well know similar type lines in Canada, Europe and Japan.

Traveller tip: no open food or drink allowed on the train and be prepared to have your bag, backpack or luggage quickly inspected at the turnstyle. Be polite about it, itâ€™s for your own safety. Bangkok takes security seriously and Iâ€™m happy that they do!

For payment you can use a ticket machine or see the teller and for a prepaid card (you choose the amount to load onto card). With a ticket, you slide it in the slot at the turnstyle and it pops in and back out (youâ€™ll need it at the exit gate, same process). With the prepaid card, all you do is swipe at the turnstyle in and again when you exit. This is how the line knows how much to charge. Some trips just a stop or two are as inexpensive as 26 baht.

My husband and I are both currently living in Bangkok and we both use the MRT and BTS daily as our primary form of transportation.

I highly recommend using the MRT and BTS to get around Bangkok.

reviewTitle: Just as easy and safe as the Skytrain!
reviewText: After several trips to Bangkok, I finally tried the MRT.  I have been a big fan and user of the Skytrain over the years given the traffic issues.  I was worried about a dark and unsafe subway adventure but true to Thailand's culture, the MRT was very clean, efficient and extremely safe.  For first timers, I suggest you google some videos that show you how to buy tickets.  Overall it runs just like the Skytrain with regards to the transit maps and boarding process.  I do suggest you bring some coins or the smallest bills to use in the auto ticket machine otherwise you'll get a lot of coins as change.  Another tip is that unless you have a multiple use card, you be issued a plastic "coin" to use on each paid trip as your ticket. The ticket machine will give you this coin.  You don't deposit the coin in the exit gate until after you trip concludes.  When first entering, you tap the coin on the machine reader and the gate opens.  This wasn't explained well on the videos I saw.  Happy Travels!

reviewText:
The Purple line is the most useful for visitors as it connects with State Railways of Thailand's commuter and long distance trains to destinations such as Chiang Mai and Surat Thani.

Underground trains are reliable, smooth and frequent although during the off peak the latter drops off a bit.

Ticketing has a day pass available but it does not seem to offer unlimited trips.

Ticketing would improve if a multi modal ticket covering BTS and MRT was introduced.

Staff are efficient and speak English, a necessity given so many foreigners who use the MRT. Stations have lifts although there are a few steps from street level to negotiate so it is not completely disabled friendly.

There are retail outlets at some stations.

Trains, as expected, are crowded during the peaks.

reviewText: There are two main transportation systems in Bangkok, other than taxis and busses.  The BTS Skytrain, like the name implies, above ground and the MRT, which is the subway.  The MRT is by far, hands down the more efficient and better managed company of the two.  Unfortunately for tourists, the BTS takes you thru the center of the city.  The MRT circles around from Hua Lampong train station to Chatujack weekend market.   MRT offers monthly passes, senior and student tickets.  No senior tickets at BTS.  The MRT has escalators from train platform to ticket counter to street.  The BTS, was just forced to put in elevators and some stations do not have them at all.  The MRT will be your best option if it takes you close to where you need to be, ex. work or school. reviewTitle: I pity the fool that goes to Bangkok and don't take the MR.T!
reviewText:
We took the MRT, (the Mr.T as we called it) as much as we possibly could, while in Bangkok, because we loved it!
It was almost impossibly clean, incredibly efficient and the other riders were beyond polite and respectful.
There is a glass wall between the waiting are and the tracks, so there is zero safety concern there. The maps are very easy to read, even for someone who speaks no Thai at all, and all of the automated ticket machines have a "switch to English" option, so even getting started is super fast and easy. The fares are based on how far you need to go, so you don't end up paying a lot for one stop like on some other systems. they dispense a little plastic token that you swipe over a sensor to get in, and then insert into a slot at the end of your ride.
We generally took it for a ride of about 9 stops, and the average fare was between 30-40 Baht,
My favourite part of taking the Mr.T (other than calling it the Mr.T) was the animated video they would play on the trains for riders, which showed what to do and not to do while using the system. It featured these adorable little sausage shaped people, and never stopped being hilarious.

reviewTitle: The Bangkok underground or something like that
reviewText:
I have been living in Bangkok since 2004, and so has the MRI. It opened just a few weeks before I arrive. It has proven its worth over the years and helped reduce the traffic in Bangkok. So this is all good and I can find nothing wrong with the service. It is still a modern service and puts the New York subway to shame.

The only problem I have consistently found is the station cooling is underpowered. During rush hour waiting for the trains can get very hot because of the mass of people in the station generating all that body heat. But with trains arriving every few minutes it is not a big problem except for people who are sensitive and can overheat quickly.

Over all if you need to get across town with minimum hassle, take the MRT or BTS.

reviewText: The MRT is an underground tube system that runs through the most important localities in Bangkok and suburbs. The older blue line originates at Hua Lamphong station and terminated at Tao Poon. The new Purple line also called the Chalong Ratchadam line originates at Tao Poon and terminates at Khlong Bang Phai currently and the rest of the line till Rat burana is yet to become operational. The minimum adult ticket is 16 bahts with gradual increments depending upon the distance. I found its more economical to travel longer distances. The Metro Malls in some important stations offer a wide variety of basic shopping. Seamless ticket booking between blue and purple lines exists however no seamless ticketing for BTS and Airport Rail Link exists although the changing stations between these do exist.

reviewText:
The MRT is easy to use and convenient as well with stations near places you want to go.

The stations are clean and well lit with cameras and security and you don't need to wait long for a train to come.Maybe 5 or 6 minutes during non rush hour.

The booth attendants spoke a bit of English and were helpful to a foreigner and pointed me the right way.

Signage is clear and good and there was no graffiti all over the place like in North America's systems.

You can use the machines or the booth to pay and as well you can connect to the BTS from the MRT.

Air conditioning works fine and ventilation was good.

reviewText:
De metro in Bangkok is een goede manier om snel een grote afstand zonder files af te leggen. Probleem is dat heel veel mensen dat ook daadwerkelijk doen zodat je, met name later op de dag (tussen 17:00 en 20:00) te maken krijgt met overvolle rijtuigen. Je moet aansluiten in de rij en ziet zo 8 of meer treinen zonder jou vertrekken. En als je dan aan de beurt bent dan sta je helemaal in elkaar gepropt en kun je met moeite uitstappen op je bestemming. Maar, al met al wel een hele ervaring en voor de avonturiers onder ons een hele happening.

Wat echt heel slecht is dat is het feit dat er "ticket vendingmachine's" staan waar je een munt moet kopen. Drie automaten die veel van de passagiers moeten voorzien van een muntje. Trek maar een half uurtje uit als je rond Silom wil instappen alleen al om een "kaartje" te krijgen.

reviewText:
The MRT subway system is easy and convenient to use. It intersects the BTS skytrain in a number of places. The largest and most central intersection is probably Asoke Station. It's clean and air conditioned. Most stations have ATMs and convenience stores nearby. There is a metal detector you'll need to pass through, but I find the security mostly perfunctory. Most locals just ignore the security if they're passing through with a small purse/slingbag. If you carry a large backpack or bag, be ready to open it to show the contents of the main compartment.

It gets very crowded at rush hour (mornings and late afternoons). There will be long queues of 15+ people at each egress/entry point. Be prepared to be squeezed in tightly if you travel during that time.

For first timers who don't speak Thai:

- Go up to a token machine, select English and then select the stop you want.
- Insert cash/coins
- Machine will dispense a dark blue plastic token as well as change (if any is due)
- Go to the entry turnstile and touch the blue token to the sensor plate to pass through
- Keep the blue token and continue to train waiting area, board train and get off at your stop
- Upon leaving through the exit turnstile, insert the blue token in the coin slot and pass through

reviewTitle: The same like by the BTS: Get a card, top it up, ride!
reviewText:
Here, applies the same review I made for the BTS!
"Thai are practical persons! That is why I do not understand why so many of them do not obtain a card for multiple rides instead of queuing up to change money, then again queuing up to buy the ticket! and that multiple times a day. It can be a nightmare during the rush hours!
I presume that now, you visitors, know what you have to do! Get a card, top it up, ride!
There is an additional benefit in buying a travel card: you do not have to search for the price of your fare! it is automatically detracted from the credit of your card.
Before you enter a train, consult the plan with the route. After you get off, consult the signs where to exit the station in order to go to your destination. Most times your destination is mentioned!â€
Only here you have one more benefit: Children and older persons get the same discount! Ask for it at the counter. You get it in both: by buying a ticket, or by obtaining a special multi ride card.

reviewTitle: Bangkok's MRT is convenient and fast- but sometimes very crowded!
reviewText: If you're in Bangkok and stay in a hotel that is close to the MRT, it's a convenient, fast way to get to where you want to go (as taxi's have to fight the traffic and Bangkok's traffic is very bad).  But watch out when you take the MRT, as peak times are very crowded.

reviewText: it is the fastest and easiest way to commute in Bangkok. The routes are pretty simple and instructions are given very clearly. The staff is helpful. You get food and some shops to buy necessary items inside the stations. there are usually two or more exits so make sure to choose your exit based on where you want to go. Frequency is good and though it is crowded you can breath and stand.

reviewText:
Bangkok is legendary for its traffic and there are times when you are in a taxi and believe you will never get out! The traffic lights turn to green but you just don't move them out the way to another few minutes for them to change again.

By far the best way around this is to use the MRT where ever possible. It's one disadvantage is that you have to use the ticket machine to pay. This can be time-consuming as you need the right change and there are a lot of tourists who are not annoyed with how the machines work.

Other than that, it is very efficient. The trains are regular, clean and nicely air-conditioned. Again, they do get very busy but it is infinitely better than trying to use the road network. Even if you are going to somewhere not on the sky train network you are best to take it as far as you can and then use a taxi from there.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Fast clean and oh so cool
reviewText:
This is a great way to get around the city, if only to cool down for a few minutes from the heat and humidity.
The link is a good way of getting to the railway station and the beginning of Chinatown to all the attractions in the Sukhumavit road area all the way down to Silom and Lumpini.
The stations all have ticket machines of ticket counters for change or tickets, the signage is easy to follow and the station guides are very clear to use.
The security is a little tighter than it used to be since the terrorist attacks on Bangkok in 2015 but this only makes you feel safer.
There is a security gate you walk through and you may be asked to open your bags as a security officer is on duty at all stations.

reviewTitle: Convenience plus a senior discount and luggage storage lockers
reviewText:
I find the MRT faster than the elevated BTS, less costly and usually less crowded.

Seniors including foreigners are eligible for half-off fares - the BTS only grants discounts to Thai citizens. However you have to queue up for each token; no multiple purchases are allowed. I wasn't asked to show any ID despite appearing under 60 years of aged.

The Sukhumvit junction gets very crowded at rush hour with waits of up to 20 minutes for a carriage. Nevertheless I chanced it to make the Petachaburi connection to the Airport Railway Link for Suvarnabhumi Airport. You can't use the elevators if you have luggage; be sure you can navigate your belongings on and off the escalators.

Finally(!) Bangkok has installed yellow "Lockbox" storage luggage lockers at most BTS and MRT stations. These come in various sizes but only accept 20 and 50 baht bills and dispense no change. Maximum rate is 40 baht/hour for the largest locker. There aren't a lot of lockers so they can fill up quickly. Nevertheless these are a godsend for travelers who need a temporary storage locker while shopping.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: A very attractive option to escape the infamous traffic jams of Bangkok.
reviewText:
Together with the BTS Skytrain light rail (which runs East to West), the fully underground MRT line links the Northern part of the city to the Southern districts. Below are my thoughts about this transportation line.

The GOOD

* Tourists can easily buy a stored value ticket at the station ticket office. The staff speak fluent English. The refundable deposit is THB 80 and the first time purchase cost THB 180. So you would have THB 100 worth of stored value. On average, the fare for two stations costs about THB 19 one way. The stored value ticket expires in 2 years.

* Clear English signage at station entrance, concourse and platforms.
* Orderly queues at platforms before boarding the train.
* Good cleanliness and housekeeping of station and platforms.
* Dual language announcements (Thai and English) in the train when a station is reached. Also safety announcement on platform gap.
* Clean air and environment and ambiance in the station and platform.
* Many stations are directly linked to shopping malls.

The BAD

* Train is congested during peak hours.
* Bag check and security gantries at all station entrances could be inconvenient if we are in a rush.
* Location of underground MRT stations is sometimes not obvious when signage along the road is lacking. For example, the Sukhumvit station entrance is not obvious for the uninitiated.

Overall, a winner mode of transport in a gridlocked Bangkok. An overall rating of 4 out of 5.

Highly recommended for tourists!

reviewTitle: Fast, frequent, inexpensive and easy to use.
reviewText:
The MRT subway system is fast, frequent, inexpensive and easy to use. Yes at peak hours it's crazy crowded and busy so try to avoid those times. All stations have great signage making it easy to navigate and there are both self serve ticket/token machines and manned ticket/token kiosks. The MRT has connections to the BTS skyway at Silom [BTS Sala Daeng], Asok [BTS Sukhumvit] and Chatuchak Park [BTS Mo Chit]. There is a connection at Petchaburi for the Airport Link line Makkasan station and at Hua Lamphong station you can take the underground walkway to Bangkok railway station, also known as Hua Lamphong, for Northern line, Northeastern line, Eastern line and Southern line trains.
The MRT subway used in conjunction with BTS skyway and the Airport rail link delivers the fastest way to get from A to B in BKK.

reviewTitle: Limited area but links with skytrain and buses.
reviewText: The MRT is the subway or tube in Bangkok.  It's very nice.  At this point it basically only serves the Central Business district but it links well with other mass transit including the vast reach of the BST or skytrain system.  One can get around quite easily in air conditioned comfort using mass transit in Bangkok.  If you don't prefer walking to your final destination, there are always car and motorcycle taxis available.  Tuk Tuks are available at the tourist spots.  I recommend them but you will be taken to shopping spots.  Spend ten minutes in the store and the driver gets fuel credit.  They usually charge less than a USD for 2 hours.  If you just want to go somewhere, ask for the "no shopping price"

reviewText: We used the MRT to travel from Hua Lamphong (chinatown) to the Saturday market on the other side of the city. The trip of 15 stops cost a very small amount of THB and took about 30 minutes, so it's also a very efficient way to travel. We also liked the experience - compared to the London underground it was a very calm trip with people giving space to others, talking in hushed tones and sharing friendly smiles. The system operates on tokens that you buy and place in the turnstiles when you reach your destination, due to this you can't buy a return 'ticket', but it's really not a hassle.

For going to Chatuchak Weekend market - get off at Khamphaen Phet MRT Station- which is in the heart of the Market itself.

reviewTitle: A Major Component Of How I Beat Bangkok's Infamous Traffic Jams
reviewText:
I am a lifetime resident of Bangkok. I love this vibrant city, but I (like all rational people) absolutely hate its horrendous traffic jams. Which is why I do not drive in the city any more. In fact, I avoid road transportation (e.g. taxis and buses) as much as I possibly can -- not totally avoidable but taken as last option. Rather, I resort to alternative travel routes, such as rail transits (MRT, BTS and Airport Rail Link), and canal/river ferries (Saen Saep Boat Service, Chao Phraya Express Boat).

MRT currently has two lines. The Blue Line (the original line) runs in a semi-circle around the perimetre of the inner city, and the Purple Line (opened in 2016) runs from one end of the Blue Line to the northwestern suburb area of Bangkok. MRT and BTS jointly serve Bangkok very well, and can get passengers to almost all commercial and residential areas of the inner city. The two systems has three convenient interchanges. However, their ticketing systems are separate, which can be quite confusing, especially if you purchase a single fare for each time you use a train. The best way to overcome this confusion is to purchase a stored-value card (available for both MRT and BTS) that you can reuse and top-up as needed -- I am not sure, but I think that you can return the card for a refund on the amount not used. I have been told that MRT and BTS fares are quite expensive compared to those of other countries, but compared to the amount of your precious time saved from having to sit in the road traffic, it is more than worth it.

Station design of MRT comply quite closely with the "universal design" concept (although not quite 100%), and so is reasonably friendly to the physically challenges. This is not so with BTS. While BTS management has put in some efforts and investments to eliminate this shortfall, but much more need to be done.

Up until 2017, BTS and MRT serve primarily Bangkok's inner city, but several more lines reaching out to the outlying areas are scheduled to be completed within the next two to three years.

reviewText:
The MRT system in Bangkok has one line.

It is a very clean, modern and efficient system. During peak hours, there are trains every five minutes. During off peak hours, trains run every ten minutes.

The train fare depends on the number of stations you travel. For one stop, you pay 15 Bahts. For two stops - 18 Bahts. 3 - 20 Bahts, 4- 22 Bahts, 5 - 24 Bahts, 6 - 26 Bahts, 7 - 29 Bahts, 8 - 31 Bahts. and so on. Children and elderly passengers pay half these amounts. Tickets are in the form of a plastic token which you tap on the ticket barrier to allow you to enter. At the end of your journey, you insert the token into the ticket barrier - and the barrier opens up for you to exit. The MRT is a very cheap and quick way of getting round Bangkok. I visited in May 2017 when the exchange rate GBP/Bahts was 44.5.

The MRT is connected to the BTS system at Asok station. If you buy a day travel card for the BTS system, you can only use it on the BTS skytrain system. It is not valid for the MRT system. I believe that the authorities should try and combine the two systems together - so that one travel card is valid for both the systems.

reviewTitle: Clean and efficient, but not extensive
reviewText:
Just like BTS Skytrain system, I am surprised that MRT, Bangkok's underground metro system, counts as one of the "attractions/things to do" in Bangkok.Though it does not rank as high as BTS (which is No. 2), at No. 19 (as of June 2017), it is still a surprise in a city with so many things to see and do. Just like BTS, I consider Bangkok MRT merely as a tool to get around to see the real "sights."

Yes, it is clean and efficient and relatively new. I think it is also more spacious than Skytrains. However, its network is not extensive enough. Several areas of interest to tourists, like Kao San Road, Royal Palace, and Wat Po, cannot be accessed by skytrains or underground metro.

Also, you can not connect MRT directly to BTS Skytrain system. Even they are next to each other in several locations (such as Silom/Sala Daeng), people using one cannot transfer to the other seamlessly. You need to get out of the station, use a new ticket and get into the other one. This does cause some inconvenience.

reviewTitle: Fast and cheap travel in Bangkok
reviewText: MRT Underground along with the BTS Skytrain is the best way to get around Bangkok. You beat all the notorious traffic which can hold you up for hours (literally) at peak times, even though taxis are cheap and reliable. If you plan carefully, you can use the MRT or BTS to get to or get close to most of the main tourist attractions in the city, as well as the main shopping areas (Sukhumvit Road). MRT and BTS intersect at various points making it easy to use both for a specific trip (though you have to pay separately for each of them). If you have to, use MRT or BTS to get as close as possible to your destination, then use taxi for the last bit.

reviewTitle: An efficient underground rail system which  integrated with other major transport facilities.
reviewText:
Travelling around heavy traffic and congestion city central in Bangkok to variety of tourist attractions and shopping centres is best via BTS or MRT.
MRT provides quick easy efficient air conditioned underground rail service , you can purchase station to station token, daily pass or best value is a 3 day pass for 230 bht.
I found the MRT easy to navigate. Clear signs and very reliable. The price to ride was good and ride was conducive. The trains are also well air-conditioned and a great place to escape the heat, even temporarily.
This rail system been integrated with BTS or ARL at some stations. It was fast, economical , and air conditoned. Unfortunately, the payment system was not integrated with BTS Skytrain Many popular and tourist attraction venues located with close proximity of the MRT stations.
Although obviously some peak times are best avoided due to the crowds, most other times there's plenty of room.
There is also the airport link for tourist who travel light .
. MRT uses token and BTS uses card. It will further enhance efficiency of both rail links if they are using the same system so that we will not have to change all the time or line up to purchase tickets at the machines which is usually very crowded.
Public announcement in the trains and the stations are in both Thai and English. Relevants maps of Bangkok city available at the stations for tourist .
The maps exhibited are also user friendly and easy to understand.

reviewTitle: Clean, quiet, easy to use once you understand the ticket/coin system
reviewText: Bangkok streets are often clogged with traffic.  If the underground rail is near your destination, take it.  Especially outside of rush hour, day or evening.  It is clean and feels very safe.  Riders obey the 4 yellow arrows on the platform - passengers exit straight out before anyone enters from the sides.  So simple, so efficient, so needed in many western subways!  For single rides, purchase a plastic coin from one of the machines in the station.  When entering, there is no slot for  the coin.  The coin has a sensor - place it on the turnstile reader and enter.  To exit, deposit the coin in the slot to release the turnstile.   Use the underground rail!  So much better than sitting in taxis in traffic.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Security Check is Terrible at the ASOKE BTS, Sukhumvit Line
reviewText: I have been living in Bangkok for two years and the have seen the security check at the BTS station go through several stages of security check standards. These days, they most just check people with bags, but the business brief cases are almost never checked.  Today, I went with my wife to early morning appointment and when it was over went to the Asoke BTS so she could return home and I could travel to work. As we were going through the gate, we were in deep conversation when suddenly, the security guard (young man who looked like he was having a bad day) basically yelled at me to get my briefcase checked. If this was the standard for everyone, then I would feel much safer, but that is clearly not the case.  This was pure and simple, harassment of a non-Thai citizen. He even had a smirk on his face when he cleared it with his wand, but still had me open my brief case.  The MRT should be aware of this happening.

reviewText:
Along with the BTS Skytrain system, the MRT is by far the quickest and easiest way to get around Bangkok and is very cheap to travel on. The trains are clean, safe and very frequent.

You can make use of the coin operated ticket machines or the counter staff to buy tickets, just tell them where you want to go and they will let you know the price.

TIP. Try to avoid using the MRT and BTS during the usual morning and afternoon rush hour periods as it can get cramped but nothing different from any other train system in major cities around the world.

reviewText:
The MRT takes you to the corners of Bangkok unaccessible by the BTS

Built 8 years after the BTS, the MRT is brilliantly designed, signposted and efficiently run. Arm yourself with the map and when in doubt ask for help from the always courteous staff.

Ask for and claim you Senior Citizen concessions (often 50%) at the ticket booths.

The Thai's have a culture that is truly respectful, always show geat self control and have a non-confrontational attitude. Be sure , that as a tourist you reciprocate

reviewTitle: It'll get you where you need to be
reviewText:
The MRT (Metro) is very clean and efficient, and appropriately chilled (okay, you could hang meat in there). And it extends to many areas you can't reach by BTS.

But.....you can't see much from underground, and the ticketing system is painful, particularly at the interchanges with the BTS.

Add to that the BTS and MRT don't play well together, so be prepared to have to reticket when you connect, and allow yourself a few minutes for this process. Similar to some major Japanese cities.

There are rumours that the systems will be unified under one transit card some time in the future, but not yet.

reviewTitle: MRT is an Excellent way to travel in Bangkok.
reviewText:
I only have positive things to say about MRT system. When I used it on occasion, it was clean, fast, cool and effective way to travel. It has only one line (blue) and it is a good way to get to the railway station HuaLamphong.
I was bit surprised they do not use all the space they have for commerce, but it is a positive for me as it keeps the walkways clean. I used the purple line (BST) and blue line and found it a good way to travel. The purple line, which is operated by BST, was very underused n, the blue line MRT was busier, but never crowded. They use security gates, to enter the station, but it is bit too relaxed to be really effective. If you need to transfer to purple line sky train, there is free shuttle bus at Bang Sue, as the connection is not finished yet. (As of March 2017).

reviewText:
The operational hours are: 6AM till Midnight
The signage & announcements are also in English.
The MRT Underground Train is a great way to get around to many parts of the city. Especially, when you consider the terrible BKK traffic, which can effect taxis. The cars are air conditioned. During my 8 days in BKK, I rode the MRT at all sorts of times/hours and never had a problem. This included rush hour.
I purchased an "Adult" stored value card. This saved me from waiting in the long lines for the vending machines which provide the coins used for paying fares. And also the long line for purchasing tickets.
The fare depends on how far you are travelling.
Some of the popular stations are: Chatuchak & Kamphaeng Phet (Exit 2) for Chatuchak Weekend Market.
Hualamphong - for train station & Wat Traimit (Golden Buddha) & Chinatown. Also for train to Ayutthaya from Hualamphong Train station.
Sukhumvit MRT - For Asok BTS area
Bang Sue - Also for train to Ayutthaya
The MRT connects with the Airport Rail Link at Makassan ARL station for Petchaburi MRT station.
And also there are intechange connecting points for switching to the BTS.
The MRT & BTS tickets are not interchangeable, they are separate systems.
Look at a MRT map on Google.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText: Our motel was 2 mins from Hwai Khwang underground station. This is such an efficient way to get around Bangkok. It is easy to use - collect all your change for cheap travel tokens but ticket machines change notes, too. There is also the option of a ticket counter but the machines have an English screen option and are easy. If you are not in a hurry and travel between 10am and 3pm-ish you will have short wait times. In the peak time morning and evenings be prepared for longer queues and being packed like a sardine. The good thing is that at peak times the trains run every couple of minutes. This is all part of the adventure of Bangkok - give it a go! The best rail destination is Chatuchack Flower Market.

reviewText:
The Bangkok underground system (MRT) is a useful and cheap method of getting around the city. There are escalators and lifts to the platform levels(s), it has efficient A/C, it never seems to get too crowded and it has an interchange with the Airport Rail Link (ARL) and two with Skytrain (BTS).

So what's not to like? Not much really apart from it doesn't really go to many useful destinations and there is only one line. While there are several lines planned or under construction, it will be several years until they're operational.

It's worth bearing in mind that Bangkok's three city rail lines are run by separate organisations and consequently use different ticketing systems. This is not user friendly at all and requires different pre-pay cards.

reviewTitle: World Class Metro Ride - smooth, convenient, comfortable and enjoyable!
reviewText: We used Metro for travelling from Si Lom to Chatuchak station. Neat and elegant stations. You can use vending machines for buying tickets. Balance amount if any, will be dispensed in coins only. Since the stations are multi-leveled, check the platform you need to go. Since it was a Saturday, perhaps it was less crowded and we got seats. However, on the way the train got filled. Found each passenger one minding own business - singles, mostly busy with internet browsing, social media, listening to music through their ear phones and others in groups of 2-3 persons engaged in conversation among themselves but not louder. Found mostly everybody decently dressed; grandmother to granddaughter almost same style - Tees/shirts and shorts but not indecent. Public announcements in the train including safety requirements to be followed by travelers were made in both local language and English and were very clear and could be easily followed by a foreign tourist. It was a World Class Metro Ride which was smooth (by avoiding traffic), convenient, comfortable and enjoyable!

reviewTitle: The best way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: Bangkok is a vast city and at certain times it gets gridlocked where traffic comes to a standstill. We have found the best way to get around is with the BTS Skytrain and MRT Underground. This is a cheap efficient way to get around and with a bit of prior research you can access most of the main parts of the city. The trains are clean, air conditioned, on time and normally packed as this is also a popular way of travel for the locals however we have never felt uncomfortable. The MRT is cheaper than the BTS and uses discs rather than cards. The network is not as extensive as the BTS and caters more for the residential areas and the Chao Praya River and the ferries. There are extensions presently under construction which will add additional links to the BTS and previous areas not serviced. There are presently four transit stations where one can access the BTS Stations. You can buy either single trip tickets or if you are planning to visit Bangkok often or for more than a week then think about buying one of the more permanent tokens which are valid from a few days to longer periods as and when required this can save time during busy periods and takes the need for small change for the single tokens out of the equation.

reviewText:
This is a modern mode of travel which makes moving around Bangkok a breeze. However, there is only one like and it does not support all of the areas, but does link up to the other transportation options such as the SkyTrain and the Klong Ferry.

For those new to this the tickets are priced based on your start and end station and this is published on the way in, and then you buy a token for the single trip. The officials are all very efficient and friendly, and it will cost you around 20-50B per one way trip which is reasonable by international standards.

The trains stop exactly at specific points on the platform, and there are clear places which you need to stand to allow the exiting passengers to get out with ease. No pushing and no jumping the queue, with everyone lining up correctly behind each other ready to enter.

Most of the people are standing, but this is not a problem since you may only move a few stations.

We used this as our base more of transport given that our hotel was outside of the central areas, but was very close to the MRT station. Well done Bangkok - a rail system which truly works.

reviewText: A very good transport option, especially during rush hours. Stations and trains are very clean. All stations have lifts and escalators internally. The exits to ground level might not be wheelchair accessible though (only escalators available). There is a crowd during rush hours which is typical of city subways just like other cities. The MRT system stops at many key local attractions, like Chatuchak area (Kampheng Phet and Chatuchak Park MRT), Union Mall (Phahon Yothin MRT), Talad Rod Fai Ratchada Train Market (Thailand Cultural Centre MRT),   Lumphini Park / Silom area (same name MRT), and Chinatown / Yaowarat area (Hua Lamphong MRT) It also provide convenient transfers to the BTS sky train at Chatuchak Park MRT <-> Mo Chit BTS and Sukhumvit MRT <-> Asoke BTS, and also a link to the Suvarnabhumi Airport rail link at Phetchaburi MRT <-> Makkasan Station of Airport Link.

reviewText:
MRT merupakan salah satu moda transportasi umum berbasis rel di Bangkok. Berbeda dengan BTS (Skytrain) yang lintasannya melayang, MRT Blue Line memiliki jalur yang seluruhnya berada di bawah tanah. Stasiunnya luas, lapang, modern, dan dilengkapi fasilitas umum seperti ATM. Tiket dapat dibeli dengan ticket vending machine yang canggih, lebih modern dari ticket machine BTS. Nanti akan keluar sebuah token hitam sebagai tiket. Ada juga MRT Stored Value Card untuk penduduk lokal dengan frekwensi tinggi menggunakan MRT.

Peron dilengkapi dengan Safety Screen Doors untuk meminimalisir kecelakaan penumpang yang jatuh ke lintasan. Armada keretanya nyaman dengan AC, dilengkapi voice-over yang memberitahukan stasiun berikutnya dalam bahasa Inggris dan Thai. Meski tidak saling terintegrasi dengan BTS dan ARL (kereta bandara), tapi penumpang mudah berpindah jalur karena tersedia walkway atau jembatan.

Fyi, MRT Purple Line sudah beroperasi bulan Agustus 2016 dan melayani rute Tao Poon sampai Provinsi Nonthaburi. Sayangnya Purple Line belum terhubung dengan Blue Line. Jadi dari Bang Sue, harus naik shuttle bus dulu ke Tao Poon.

reviewTitle: Very easy way to get around the bustling city of Bangkok.
reviewText:
We found that the train system in Bangkok is very well run. It is very affordable, trains run very frequently, and are very well presented and kept clean. The ticketing system was very easy to use. Good if you can avoid peak times as it gets very busy. 18 stations in all running from Bang Sue to Hua Lamphong, next to Chinatown. reviewTitle: An easy way to get around Bangkok, a great system MRT
reviewText:
The MRT is a great underground rail system that also connects to the BTS Sky rail .
You might find your first experience obtaining your ticket a little difficult as it is different to the BTS system, the touch screen is the same system as used on the MTR in Hong Kong, so if you have used that system it will be easy.

The system is in Thai and English so select English and if you know the station where you want to go to then touch that station and you will see your fair come up, insert your money and out will come a round disc, you swipe the disc as you go through the entrance and when you are leaving you insert the disc into the slot and the gate opens.

If you are uneasy about using the system for the first time then go to the office and buy your disc there as the staff are very good and very helpful, I would suggest trying to use the system during the quiet time as at peak times there are hundreds of people all lined up waiting to get there disc.

If you are going to be in Bangkok for a few days or longer and using the MRTa lot i would suggest you buy a ticket from the office as you can top up the ticket at any MRT office for as little as 100 Baht = Aust $4 the card will cost you a few dollars and is not refundable but the time you will save standing in lines and having to carry change for your ticket then it is well worth while, i use the card all the time as it is so easy and quick and very quick to top up.

The MRT is a very fast service and if you miss one train there is usually another train with in about 4 minutes, the trains are very clean and like the BTS there is no drinking or food to be eaten and do not leave your rubbish on the train take it with you and show respect for the other people.

Entering the MRT station is the same as the BTS there are security guards to inspect your bags and luggage as they are there for all our safety. When on the station stand behind the yellow line and to the side of the entrance to the train that allows the people to get off and makes it easy to get on, that is the same system as the BTS.

reviewTitle: ANOTHER SECRET WEAPON AGAINST BANGKOK TRAFFIC GRIDLOCK
reviewText: The MRT system is relatively new. It is an undereground train system that compliments the elevated train system known as the BTS or â€œSky Trainâ€. The two systems share several adjacent locations to ease transition from one to the other, most notably the Asoke intersection on the BTS Sukumvit line. Best advice: find the station closest to your destination in the city and go there via the BTS and MRT. Once at that station it will be easy to hail a cab for the final leg, thus reducing your total transit time significantly. As with the BTS system and eco-world has blossomed around the street level of most stations where you will find â€œstreetâ€ food vendor as well as flower and various hawkers of goods.

reviewText: During my visit to Bangkok I have mainly used the MRT to go to Hua Lumphong to Silom after strolling around Chinatown both during the day and in the evening. The underground is incredibly clean, efficient and cool compared to the heat outside; i have also noted it never gets too busy as there are trains very often and given its slight high price (for Thai standards at least). Overall I was very pleased whenever I used it and I suggest it as a safe, traffic free means of transportation to everyone.

reviewText:
The MRT Underground Train is in good company in Bangkok with the BTS Skytrain - both provide public transport at a world class standard. If you're staying within close proximity to one the stations of either service, they should be your primary transport whilst in Bangkok - if you're not staying within close proximity, I suggest you should consider relocating!

If the MRT doesn't get you to one of the must-see attractions around Bangkok, the Skytrain likely will - and vice-versa.

Skytrain offers the views of BKK whilst perched above the ground in air-conditioned comfort, but MRT stations provides a reprieve from the heat whilst waiting for air- conditioned trains to come along.

The MRT and Skytrain each have an interchange station with the Airport Train to and from the basement of Suvarnabhumi Airport - again, a great world class service that gets you as close to the airport as a taxi does. I'm also a huge fan of the Airport Train (cheap, very reliable and avoids horrendous traffic), and there's another airport link being constructed at the moment (Sep 2016) to service BKK's other major airport at Don Mueang.

reviewTitle: One of the best ways to explore BKK
reviewText:
The under ground rail network of BKK is called MRT and is one of the best and fastest ways to get to many places in BKK . It will save you huge time , much cheaper than taxi.

There are several stations where MRT meets the SKY train (BTS) and one can use BTS / MRT to reach most of part of main city and surroundings area.

A bit of study of maps of city and finding out best combination to use BTS /MRT to reach closest point to your destination, will save you so much of time and money and you can explore much more of this lovely city without getting tired and frustrated with traffic of the city.

Trains and stations are very clean, the staff is very helpful and even commuters are very helpful. All boards are in also in English and Thai . Announcement of approaching stations are made inside the train. So you are sure you will never get lost .

great way to live like locals and explore city with time and money saving.. More importantly time.

reviewText:
Using the MRT and BTS you can explore a lot of Bangkok without sitting in time wasting traffic.

Although the BTS is bigger and has better A/C than the MRT, I prefer the latter because it has 1, 3 and 30 day unlimited monthly passes and you get to wait for it underground where the temperature is much cooler.

The BTS and MRT interchange at two stops: Mo Chit and Asoke/Sukhumvit.

Like the BTS, the MRT does get very crowded during peak hours and I would recommend avoiding Sukhumvit and stops adjacent to it during this time.

reviewText: People are usually surprised to find out that the mass transport systems in bangkok - both the MRT and BTS sky train, are both clean, efficient and affordable. The MRT is the underground version of the sky train and runs to various areas within Bangkok not within the overhead versions routes. It goes to strategic stops such as Hua Lampong - where the main train station is, Lumpini - where the end of a big park starts/ends and Sukhumvit - where the connection to the sky train is located. Buying a token is easy: either at the counter or at the machines and the ride is user friendly. There are maps, guides and announcements being made prior every stop. All in all, a very good experience.

reviewTitle: Cool way to travel and avoid heat and traffic
reviewText: It used to be said that if there were more three or four people in a group, a taxi was not much more than BTS or MRT fares. But that does not take into account the dramatic increase in traffic in Bangkok in recent years. Provided your starting point and destination are not too far away, the MRT is always going to be a cooler and, often, faster option. But I do wish the ticket machines had the option of buying multiple tickets at the one time. I suppose if you are going to use the system a lot, it would make sense to get a stored value card. I didn't need a toilet when at the station but I don't recall seeing any.

reviewText: Going by MRT is definitely more convenient compared to the crowded and poorly maintained BTS. Stations are spacious and trains are modern, clean and follow international safety standards. Only network is more limited but work for expansion is already in progress. Don't expect anything like the Octopus Card in Hong Kong, the BTS runs a different system to MRT and in case you need to continue by bus it's again another system. But frequency of MRT is great even it would be more professional in case arrival and time between trains would be displayed. If possible I always prefer MRT over the BTS.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText: This underground system is extremely good, clean and efficient. Once the new lines are completed then it will be the preferred way of navigating the city (in conjunction with the Skytrain) and have a longer range too.

reviewText: The MRT is a great mode of transportation while in Bangkok. My suggestion to visitors is to get the card where you can put a certain amount of money on it, so you don't have to keep going to the machines.

reviewText: Have used the MRT a few times over the last few days, and it is so easy to use. The stations are huge and air conditioned! There are signs in both Thai and English and when using the ticket machines there is the choice to have an English screen. Travel is cheap and so organized.  There are arrows to tell you where to stand or walk.  It is funny to see the huge stations when they are empty, but during peak hour you can see why they are so big. Today I even dragged a huge piece of luggage around on the MRT and did not have any problems. There are lifts in most areas, although in a few random places you will need to use stairs.  Thai people are so friendly and try to help if they see that you are struggling. Beats sitting in traffic.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Let's check the newly opened MRT Purple line
reviewText: This is the 4th route of mass transit system in Bangkok named Bangsue (Tao-poon station) -( Bang Pai and) Bang Yai, a large community on the  outskirt west of Bangkok, which exactly is another province (Nonthaburi). My wife and I catched the train from Tao Poon station which is only 5 minutes walk from our home  to Bang Yai, the second last station on the other end. It takes sround 30 minutes which cost 42 bath for one trip- the highest rate for the entire route ride. The train is new (ofcourse) but....(1) ticket vending machine is not enough especially at Bang Yai station which is a large station with lots of commutor. (2) It also difficult to insert  one-baht coin into the slot as it always go down to the change-bin; not into the right path in the machine, thus take a long time for each passenger to complete ticket buying.(3) The electronic gate entering/exit the platform is also not enough (some of them are out of order-both at Tao Poon and Bang Yai station) (4) The train braked quite hard when entering station as if they had not enough time to train the driver. (5) Electronic sign board indicating station on left-hand side of the train did not work properly in both train we rode. (6) The signage indicating point to get a transfer bus to Underground MRT Bangsue has to be visible easily and sufficient. I wonder how hectic it would be in rush hour on working day if passenger have to wait in long line to get a ticket or even to get out of the station. (7) Last but not least, the government should enforce MRT to operate the blue line connecting between Tao poon station and Bang Sue station as soon as possible, as it is not practical to transfer to bus to connect to underground train to ride downtown (which would take more than 20 minutes when the traffic is bad ). Hope to see improvement soon!

reviewTitle: TRANSPORT FOR LONDON COULD LEARN HERE
reviewText:
Fed up battling with taxi drivers who refused to use their meters and dangerously driven tuk tuks I took to the Metro. I'm glad that I did.

Everything was spotlessly clean and that included the helpful staff. Other travellers were happy to help the dithering European in front of the automatic ticket machine. My change included a Â£2 coin size plastic disc and this was my ticket.

The platforms are sensibly marked with queuing spots for passengers getting on, leaving space for passengers getting off. Ok I was not travelling in the rush hour but it certainly works when there are not too many punters.

It's a great system and the staff and other local travellers are charming and helpful. It costs a pittance and you should try it. Remember it's an underground so no views. You'll need Skytrain for that.

reviewTitle: Beat the Bangkok Traffic and Heat.
reviewText:
I worked in Bangkok for a couple of years and go back frequently. Getting around the city is the same kind of art as most major cities. You have to learn to mix and match different kinds of transportation to get exactly were you want to go. As in most cities traffic can get unmanageable. Bangkok also has some intense heat which needs to be considered. The MRT Subway system is a key part of the options available and stays cool year around.
To my knowledge there are no plans to build anymore subway tunnels in BKK because of some of the challenges which were found building the current tunnels. Future expansion will be above ground and involve the BTS SkyTrain System. Still the interconnectivity of the single MRT line with the two BTS lines works well to get you generally close to where you want to go in most parts of Central Bangkok.
The MRT is very clean and runs very efficiently. Did I mention it is always cool. There are security check points at each station and restrictions on things which can be brought onto the train: plan ahead.
Modesty needs to be set aside during commute times in the morning and the evening. The MRT is heavily used and physical contact on all four sides at the same time is not uncommon. Personal hygiene is appreciated by everybody.

I can no longer image Bangkok without the MRT. Did I mention it is cool year around.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Between the MRT and BTS you can see much of Bangkok
reviewText: Before the MRT there was the BTS, aka the Skytrain.  The BTS, which is above ground, is a relatively modern train line that covers a reasonable amount of the city.  More recently the MRT, a subway (or underground) added a number of stops where the BTS did not go.  The MRT is also relatively modern, very clean, and fairly easy to figure out.  Particularly given the number of "shady" taxi and tuk-tuk drivers in Bangkok, getting an MRT and BTS map, and then using both systems during a visit to Bangkok, is almost essential.

reviewTitle: Puts New York Metro to shame!
reviewText: Yes, I know it's much newer than the New York Metro, so you might expect it to look more modern - but when you compare other heavily used metros (such as London, Paris, Moscow) with New York, you really wonder why they can't even attempt to keep up with the standards achieved by other major cities? (Rhetorical question - I assume the answer is mostly down to politics). So in Bangkok, the metro is pristine - so clean you feel you could almost eat food from the floor. The platforms have security screens to prevent accidental falls to the lines; and the other side of the glass, on tunnel walls, are movie screens for advertising, reminiscent of Blade Runner! Announcements on the train are both in Thai and in English, as are the signs. Easy to navigate and great connections with the Skytrain (BTS). The MRT and BTS have made getting around Bangkok so easy.

reviewTitle: It gets you there...get a mrt card to save time
reviewText:
MRT is the underground subway system for metro bangkok. Here is a few things you need to know:

- great for single travelers or even small groups to beat traffic, especially when the destination is very close by to the station. During peak traffic times, it is sometimes faster to take MRT to nearby destination, and then take taxi/tuk-tuk or local bus from there.

- air condition is strong inside train like the SRT. You can take a light jacket, but it is only for a short time. Good way to beat the daytime heat though

- Unfortunately, the rabbit card is not compatible with MRT, so you will need a separate card for MRT. Like BTS, the MRT ticket queue can get quite large and it could mean waiting 15-20 minutes just to get a token. So MRT reloadable pass or multi-day passes might be more convenient.

- connects with lots of popular destinations, especially Hua Lamphong which is the SRT main station (ground level, inter-province trains)

reviewTitle: Excellent Option to Commute with Bangkok
reviewText:
The MRT is great to get around Bangkok. This is mostly underground and has two lines.

The only issue is MRT Pass cannot be used on other public transports. If a single Pass could be usable across BTS, MRT, BRT, RailLink and Ferries it would be great.

You needs bank notes to buy machines from Vending machines or you can get it from counter. I would suggest to go for the Pass which you can get for 180 THB. 30 THB is the issuing fee and will not be refunded and 50 THB is the deposit. If you are going to travel extensively ON MRT (remember MRT does not cover all the major attractions and the pass is not usable on other transports so this may be costly) for 3 days you could go for the 3 day pass which would be cheaper.

reviewTitle: Fine if you need to go that way
reviewText:
Been in Bangkok many times but never had the need to use the MTR. Did this time as wanted to get to Jim Thompson shop's near Silom from Asoke. MTR clean and fast and cheap. The only problem is that there is only one line and does not cover many of the areas that a tourist would want to go. BTS is rather better as has 2 lines, but again covers a rather limited area but good for trips up and down Sukhumvit in air conditioned luxury, when its 40C outside!!!!!
The BTS does provide a good link to the express river buses to get you to the Royal Palace, Wat Poo & Aran and adds to the travel experience. All three modes of transport are cheap too.

reviewTitle: use MRT and BTS when in Bangkok to get around

reviewTitle: MRT is not Mass and not Rapid at all
reviewText:
If you don't mind wating upto 5 minutes (hell! FIVE minutes) for something called RAPID, half day dangerously overcrowded so passengers has to que to wait another train (mass, ha?) quite expensive for such short distances, watching poor girls standing a the Security Gates without even chance to sit and lean on anything ... Airconditions barely working at 50% of stations, some entrances do not have elevators - so old people have to do 100 steps walk down !!!
Again, some stations in the Asoke, Silom area are dangerously overcrowded. it is dangerous gathering of too many people in single place, if you can understand whats the treat.
Bangkok MRT is the best example how to build something on shoestring budget. Great it exists, great respect to hardworking staff of MRT, and hope ther would be more trains running faster and more frequently

reviewTitle: Easy, inexpensive way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: Wow, my city should take lessons from this metro system!  Fast, clean, efficient and cheap transportation system.  Don't be intimidated.  Look at the metro map, figure out what station you need to get to, then look up the price on the chart located at the cashier.  You will get a small black coin/disk.  Simply swipe this on the screen at the turn stall.  At your destination you need to use this coin to get out of the station.  Easy.

reviewText:
The MRT is the underground part of the Bangkok transportation infrastructure and currently has only one line running between the Hua Lamphong inter city train station and Bang Sue. It covers downtown Bangkok in addition to China town, Lumpini Park, Cultural Centre and Chatuchak park. It is connected to the other transportation networks in Bangkok like the Skytrain and Airport rail link. Unfortunately for the commuters, it uses a different kind of ticket from the Skytrain. So travellers need to break the journey and purchase another ticket if they want to change from the Skytrain to the MRT or vice versa. Fortunately, tickets can be bought easily from the automated machines at the stations.

Other than this small inconvenience, it is a very fast and comfortable way to get around Bangkok. The system is world class and comparable to any other MRT system in the world. The stations are clean, spacious and well maintained and the entire system (including the stations) is air-conditioned which offers a respite from the humid Bangkok heat outside.

The MRT offers a great way to get around Bangkok attractions and nightlife areas and is not too crowded except for peak times. It is the best way to travel around Bangkok if your destination lies on its route.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.
