reviewTitle: World Class Train System in Bangkok
reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic, a truly World-class Train System in Bangkok. A modern wonder of Marble and Stainless Steel. Everything (the Trains, Train Platform, Train Stations, etc.) are clean. The best way to travel around Bangkok Cheaply, Easily and Quickly.

Ticketing is easy using a Touchscreen which dispenses a Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) Token, and you can pay both in Coins and Paper Bills. The machine only gives changes in Coins, though. The menu is available in Thai or English, and you can choose either.

Lots of Foreigners take it, sometimes with their luggage, probably either coming from or going to the airport since the system now integrates with an Airport Line.

Foreigners tend to slow down the ticket queue a lot, though, and the Tokens and Coins are dispensed around your knee area so sometimes kind of hard to reach around and look for the Token and Coins.

There is only one line now, the Blue Line, but as I understand more are being planned. Interconnects with the BTS Skytrain seamlessly at certain stations.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Clean, nice and very quiet MRT
reviewText:
I said very quiet because not many people using MRT. Each station is big and very spacious. Plus it is clean. Not many station master can speak English, so must use the name of the place you're going to then they understand. Use the vending machine, you choose English first on the top right hand side. Press the name of the station you're going to and pay the amount by coins or paper. Then there is black plastic coin comes out, hang on to it don't loose it because this is your MRT ticket. So the black plastic coin comes out then your change. Look carefully for your change, don't left it there. Then you go the gate with the green light and there is a place to tap your black coin. Hold on to your coin, just tap it but still hang on to it. When you exit from the station, you just put the black coin on the slot, just drop it, then the gate will open.

Have a nice ride.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: What do I do with 19 stops?
reviewText:
On my last day in Bangkok, I decided to try its other modes of transportation such as the MRT, BTS, and Bus #53. i did not have happy moments with either my tuktuk drivers and taxi drivers ( overcharges).

From my hotel near Khao San Road, I took Bus 53 to Hua Lampong Station where the MRT line starts. I bought a day pass for 120 bahts, unlimited rides.

My goal was to see how the various stations look like. They don't appear to have any shops or restaurants at these stations.I stayed in the train from Hua Lamphomg to Bang Sue where all passengers had to get off. Took the train on the other side of the tracks and got off at the Chatuchak Park Station.

This station has a beautiful park near by, the Chatuchak Park. Clean public restrooms are free at the park. I bought my day pass for BTS train at the Chatuchak Train Station.

Please see my related review of BTS. Note that there might be some attractions near the MRT stations, I just did not stop by due to time constraints.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

This is by far the best transport system we have travelled on in any city in the world.
It is fast ,clean,inexpensive & extremely efficient.

If only Melbourne had installed a similar service from The Airport & around the City instead of the inefficient & expensive Myki.

reviewTitle: MRT si moda utama bagi yang kuat jalan jauh.
reviewText: Di kota mana pun yang memilikinya, MRT memang menarik untuk dicoba, demikian pula di Bangkok. Walaupun MRT di Bangkok tidak terlalu jauh jangkauannya tapi cukup membantu wisatawan untuk bepergian ke destinasi yang diinginkan. Pembelian tiket (token atau card) sangat mudah baik dengan mesin otomatis yang melayani uang kertas maupun koin ataupun langsung ke counter pelayanan. MRT ini juga tidak terlalu penuh sesak di jam sibuk jadi cukup asyik untuk digunakan selama menjelajah Bangkok. Meskipun demikian, bagi yang tidak terbiasa berjalan jauh mungkin harus berlatih lebih banyak karena naik turun dari basement ke ground cukup melelahkan apalagi kalau ingin melanjutkan ke SkyTrain harus naik lagi, lumayan capek. Walau sedikit bikin capek, namun tetap asyik dan membantu: itulah MRT di Bangkok.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

When in BKK consider MRT as a transport option. You will not be disappointed.

reviewText: There is only one line so the route/number of stops is limited.  However, there are some good stops.  The MRT goes through the Sukhumvit area which is where I stayed.  If you go in one direction to Hua Lamphong you can get to Chinatown and the Gold Buddha.  If you go the other direction you can get to the weekend market (a shopping must visit) at the second or third to the last stop at Mo Chit or Kamphaeng Phet.  There is more shopping here than you can imagine and if you only spend a full day here, you missed half the shops!  Note:  Some of the shops are outside = SUN, and most are under HOT tin roofs.

reviewText: De metro MRT is een veilige, snelle, goedkope en handige manier om je in Bangkok te verplaatsen. reviewText: The MRT is reliable, clean and you feel safe;  the maps and ticket pricing system are easy to understand and the ticket machine worked well, too (you can switch to an English version of the screen). reviewText:
Even though the MRT in Bangkok is not a huge system like London and other cities, there are some great locations to visit.
Cheaper and quicker than any tuk tuk or taxi.

I recommend you buy a day, 3 day or 5 day passes depending on the length of your stay obviously. The reason for this is it will save you queueing for tokens during busy periods.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Not quite as good as SkyTrain
reviewText: The lines for token machines in busy stations here are often way too long. They need to fix this. The easiest way would be to create a single stored-value card that can be used on this service AND SkyTrain (right now they're not compatible.) Also, seems to run with less frequency than SkyTrain.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText:
A useful transport option if you stay near one but transferring from the MRT to BTS would be a hassle as it involves exiting one station and going up and down escalators and stairs to the other station. You have to queue again to buy a separate ticket. The ticket machines at each station is limited and may be out of order too. It accepts coins, 20, 50 and 100 thb notes.

One useful tip is to buy your return ticket when you arrive at the station esp when there's no crowd yet.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText: Great way to get around central Bangkok. It's cheap, it's clean and only crowded during rush hours. Makes many stops at all the places you want to see. Great shopping and great places to eat.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewTitle: Great choice of transportation in Bangkok
reviewText:
Specially when you live in heart of Bangkok like Asoke.

This is the best way to escaped all those traffic on Sukhumvit, Ratchada Roads.

It's reliable and on time.

Buy a prepaid reloaded ticket to avoid long Q at rush time.

The price for prepaid reloaded ticket for adult is 180 THB which will deduct 50 THB deposit and 30 administration fee. The money left in card is 100 THB. For 2 bucks you save a lot of time to Q up.

This is the way to go if it meets your needs. I use the MRT every chance I can. It is cheap ,easy to use,clean and fast. Transfers to BTS. Avoid rush hours if possible as it does get crowded.
There is English announcements as well as video screens on the train showing the stops upcoming . And let's face it you can't get lost if you miss your stop just come back. Get a pocket map of the transit system and ride.

reviewText: I use the MRT when ever I can. It usually runs on time and is cheap. It also links up with the BTS at some of the bigger stations. reviewText:
I've been using MRT more than the BTS Skytrain to get around Bangkok, but the combination of the two is very powerful. I wouldn't consider staying anywhere in Bangkok that is not a short walk from one of the systems' stations. The alternative to using the two public transit systems is sitting stalled in Bangkok's traffic.

MRT is just as clean and efficient as BTS. Unfortunately it uses a different system of payment, though they are talking about using a universal card 'any year now'. If you will be riding more than a few times, I'd strongly suggest getting a pre-paid card. It will get you into the system much faster at rush hour, when the single-token machines have long queues.

A few downsides to the MRT:
1) You can only by a single token from your current station to elsewhere. You can't buy a round trip.
2) The MRT and the BTS (currently) has two separate systems for multi-trip cards.

reviewTitle: Value added underground tube in Bangkok
reviewText: We recently did our 4th trip to Bangkok in as many years. We love Bangkok for its public transport trains. Though the major lifeline for us tourists is its BTS skytrain service, the MRT is another value addition to reach areas in central Bangkok where there is no BTS. We stay at hotels a short walk from MRT Silom (& BTS Saladaeng) and simply love the Silom-Sukhumvit area. With Bangkok's very heavy road traffic, the local taxis & tuk tuks overcharging foreign tourists & local buses not very convenient for non Thai speakers, hence the importance of this value added skytrain service. All instructions are bilingual, Thai & English, with tourist friendly signs. The trains have very good air conditioning, so it acts as a dehumidifier. There are escalators at many stations too, for travellers with bags. Can get crowded during peak hours, though the crowd discipline is excellent. The only negative is the absence of return tickets, 1, 3 or 7 day passes, so beneficial for tourists.

reviewText: The MRT is fine for what it does, if what it does is what you need.  By that, it is not an extensive subway system, a la those of other great cities of the world - NY, Paris, London or Tokyo. It is a couple of lines alone high travel routes.  There is a chance it might start near where you are and go to where you want to go.  If so, you are lucky, as it is clean and efficient, and reasonably priced.  But it may require you to change from MRT to BTS, the skytrain, and as those are not part of the same system, you have to exit the MRT, and buy a new ticket for the BTS, a foolish aspect of mass transit in Bangkok.  Probably the result of some idiotic political issue, of which Thailand has many.

reviewTitle: Dit is nog maar het begin van de metro in Bangkok
reviewText: Het goed goedkoop transportmiddel om van het treinstation( hualampong) naar silom en ssumkkuvit road gaan en verder. De purpleline is aanbesteed die gaat van bang sue naar nontaburi. Maar ik denk dat men met planning een fout heeft gemaak. Men had van bang sue via thonburi weer naar hualampong moeten gaan  want een circelline is van groot lang om een goed metronet op zetten. Het is een gemiste kans maar wie weet komt het nog een keer. de planning in 2000 was een nieuwe vervoernet van metro en skytrain op te zetten van ongeveer 250 km( moet wel financieel haalbaar zijn) om Bangkok van zijn verkeersinfarct en luchtvervuiling te verlossen . Dus de in intensie is goed .maar het komt dat is zeker .  Misschien was het ook wel goed om voor de auto's  een tolsysteem op te zetten zoals in Londen en Singapore

reviewTitle: Cheap and convenient way of getting around
reviewText: Bangkok train system may not be as extensive as compared to NYC subway, but it's a cheap and quick way for getting to other parts of the city, plus our hotel was by the station making it very convenient. The stations are air conditioned, which was a relief from the heat and humidity. The only downside, trains stops running by midnight.
disclaimer: This review is the subjective opinion of a Tripadvisor member and not of Tripadvisor LLC.

reviewText: Yes they are crowded at times, but the thai people are so polite, it really is a pleasure to get around this way. It becomes methodical - insert coins, get bingo chip (lol) , go through security, insert ticket, find right direction of train, catch train to stop. It's SO easy! Much easier than I even thought it would be .... and all the stops are so clearly labeled.. Many even have (Exit 3, example, xxx mall, xxx attraction this way) clearly marked signs telling you where to find what you need - making it so easy for tourists to get around! It's cheap, it's a bit of walking but no worries, it's mostly air conditioned :)   TIP: see something at an MRT stop but on the other side of the road?? Go back into the MRT and take a  different exit. Ta daa! You're now on the other side of the road. You're welcome. It took us way too long to figure that out lol. Also, MRT is less busy than the BTS in general.. Not by much but it is noticeable.  And there don't appear to be any garbage cans or food allowed at MRT so pack it in pack it out.. Same with BTS... Though BTS has shops near ticket booths.

reviewText: Hassal free transport in the centre of Bangkok that is cool and fast, with an ever expanding network. This has interconnecting station with the BTS and even the airport link, but the walk is a little long if you have lots of baggage. Travelling at peak times ie early morning for workers and again in the early evening with workers going home it can get very crowded. If you are staying in Bangkok for any length of time pick up a multi pass that you only need to top up as required, its saves time lining up for tickets. A very clean safe, effective and cool option to transport yourself.

reviewText: My friend and I utilized this transportation option many times during our trip. While it is true, that the line might not drop you right at some attractions, it will get you close enough to cut your travel time in half and allow you to experience walking on some local streets. As of September 2015 (perhaps as a result of the recent bombings) before entering, you must walk through a metal detector and present your bag for a quick inspection. This does not seem to slow down your travel at all. There is a ticket desk, but also self service kiosks with an "English" option. Very simple to use, just indicate your destination stop, and the amount charged will display. Most machines accept 100 baht notes or under and most coins. We rode for an average of 20-25 baht (less than $1) per ride. A token will dispense that you touch to a pad to get through the "gate". At your final stop, when you exit the station, you put your coin through a slot to open the "gate". The subway is clean and efficient. Stops are announced in both Thai and English. Make sure to mind the queue indicators on the floor! As another heads up, train direction is indicated by the final (terminus) stop in each direction.

reviewTitle: Convenient connection to the BTS and to various attractions
reviewText: For solo travelers, the MRT is very convenient to get to many attractions. It takes you right to Chatuchak (weekend) market near the stalls. It also acts as a good connection to the sky train, if you're staying close to an MRT station. For instance, we were near Phra Rama 9, and we took the blue line towards Bang Sue to get to Chatuchak. You can't club the passes for the MRT and BTS though -- they use separate tickets/passes. The stations are announced in both English and Thai. The carriages and stations are neat. We found it a convenient alternative to get to many attractions that required connections to the BTS.
